attributes.title: Steinway Grand Piano Supply Chain
attributes.description: All Steinway and Sons Piano's are manufactured in two main factories, however all materials are from different parts of the world.
attributes.tags: steinway grand piano supply chain csr product

attributes.description: Steinway and Son's Japan Corporation. Grand and Upright pianos sold in Japan are first shipped to the Steinway dealer. Then, is sent to all areas across Japan for further sales.
attributes.title: 16. Steinway & Sons Japan, Ltd.

attributes.description: Louis Renners 2nd factory in Zeitz, Germany. This is where many of the hammers and action parts, created by Renner Inc. are manufactured. Then, these materials are sent to Steinways and Sons
attributes.title: 14. Louis Renner Factory - Zeitz

attributes.description: The first factories that Louis Renner owns, is used to create their action parts of grand pianos and hammers
attributes.title: 13. Louis Renner Factory - Stuttgart

attributes.description: Louis Renner is the company that provides the hammers and action parts of Steinway and Sons grand pianos. It is mostly created by hand and the drilling, milling and bushing are done with the highest degree of accuracy. These hammers are one of the most delicate part of the piano to produce sound, as tuners place tiny holes in the soft fabric, to change and modify the tone completely.
attributes.title: 12. Louis Renner Headquarters - Piano Action and Hammers
attributes.flickr:setid: "New Steinway Hammers | Piano Forum." New Steinway Hammers | Piano Forum. N.p., n.d. Web. 12 Feb. 2013. <http://www.pianostreet.com/smf/index.php?topic=512.0>.

attributes.description: The Mapes String Company was the first American piano wire company, used by hundreds of piano sellers and companies, including Steinway and Sons. The string is made from high-carbon steel, and is one of the most demanding of all applications made out of that material. They are slackened, stretched and repeatedly blown during tuning and manufacturing, so that it can last for decades.
attributes.address: Wire Mill Road, Elizabethton, TN 37643, USA
attributes.title: 8. Mapes Piano String Company

attributes.description: The Bavarian spruce is used for the piano keys of steinway keyboards. This is because the wood produces the consistent tone when vibrated.
attributes.title: 11. Bavarian Spruce Wood

attributes.description:
The cast iron plate was introduced into the grand pianos in the 1800’s, having the responsibility to sustain the massive tension that the tightened strings produce. Before the advancement in metallurgy, wood was used which would bend and warp under the high string tension, therefore changing tune very so frequently. Now, the cast iron plates are able to withstand string tension of up to 70,000 pounds. 
Steinway has bought two companies to create their cast iron plates, including the Germany manufacturing company of Kluge, and the OS Kelly Corporation in Ohio.
attributes.title: 7. Cast Iron Plate

attributes.description: The Sitka Spruce, a large evergreen tree reaching upto 80 meters tall, is used for the soundboards, the upright back posts, braces and keybeds of the pianos. This is because the wood has the benefits of extreme lightness, tremendous tensile strength in weight and unequaled sensitivity to vibrating strings.
attributes.address: Northern Alaska Tour Company, Fairbanks International Airport (FAI), 3820 University Avenue South, Fairbanks, AK 99709, USA
attributes.title: 1. Sitka Spruce Wood

attributes.description: This expensive cabinet wood is used for the exposed furniture parts, including the outer rims and frames. It is steamed for the uniformity in colour and its exquisiteness of character. The wood is cut into long layers and are added onto the outer side of the maple wood, used for the rim of grand pianos.
attributes.title: 6. Black Walnut Wood

attributes.description: Mahogany wood, a very popular dark wood used for woodworking, is mainly applied to the legs of grand and upright pianos, keybed molding and the pedal layers.
attributes.title: 9. Mahogany Wood

attributes.description: Quarter-Sawn Yellow Poplar is used for the corewood, such as the veneers, in both grand and upright pianos, as well as the key lids and upright sides. This is because it has the ability to retain its flat or rounded posture as the corestock.
attributes.title: 5. Yellow Poplar Wood

attributes.description: The yellow birch is one of the toughest birch trees, having the extreme hardness of interlocking grains, known as ‘curly grains.’ This wood is used for the keybed caps, linings, backboard and piano legs of Steinway pianos.
attributes.title: 15. Yellow Birch Wood

attributes.description: The Quarter-Sawn Maple is used for the rest planks and bridges of the grand piano because it has the greatest ability to attain a vise-like grip on the tuning pins and bridge pins, once drilled in. 240 holes are created in this maple wood for the bridge pins, 1 hole for each string.
attributes.title: 4. Quarter-Sawn Maple Wood

attributes.description: Hard Maple is used for the action parts and rims of the grand piano because it is the whitest maple wood, and has a flexible shape retention, with great durability. The wood is cut into long layers which reaches over seven meters, glued together to create thickness, then bent into a piano shape in a metal press.
attributes.title: 3. Piano Grade Hard Maple

attributes.description: The second and oldest factory for Steinway and Sons is currently in Germany, Hamburg. All materials to manufacture pianos are sent to this factory. Each grand piano is built by approximately 450 people, each working on different parts.
attributes.title: 10. The Steinway Factory - Germany

attributes.description: Found in the 19th century, this factory is the main manufacturing factory for Steinway and Sons' pianos. Heinrich Engelhard Steinweg, the founder of Steinway and Sons, created a ‘company town’ where all infrastructure and business of the town were owned by a single corporation. Currently, all suppliers and materials are sent to this factory, and built with over 450 people, per grand piano.
attributes.address: Allegany College of Maryland, 6022 Glades Pike, Somerset, PA 15501, USA
attributes.title: 2. The Steinway Factory - United States
